Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic Administrative Divisions:

Kraya, Oblasti, Cities of Republican Subordination, Autonomous Oblasti, Autonomous Okruga and National Okruga

Kraya: Altay - Khabarovsk - Krasnodar - Krasnoyarsk - Primorskiy - Stavropol - Oblasti: Amur - Arkhangelsk - Astrakhan - Belgorod - Bryansk - Chelyabinsk - Chita - Gorkiy - Irkutsk - Ivanovo - Kalinin - Kaliningrad - Kaluga - Kamchatka - Kemerovo - Kirov - Kostroma - Kurgan - Kursk - Kuybyshev - Leningrad - Lipetsk - Magadan - Moscow - Murmansk - Novgorod - Novosibirsk - Omsk - Orenburg - Oryol - Penza - Perm - Pskov - Rostov - Ryazan - Sakhalin - Saratov - Smolensk - Sverdlovsk - Tambov - Tomsk - Tula - Tyumen - Ulyanovsk - Vladimir - Volgograd - Vologda - Voronezh - Yaroslav - Cities of Republican Subordination: Moscow - Leningrad - Autonomous Oblasti: Adygey - Gorno-Altay - Karachayevo-Cherkess - Khakass - Yevreyskaya - Autonomous Okruga: Agin Buryat - Chukotka - Evenkiyskiy - Khanty-Mansi - Komi-Permyak - Koryak - Nenets - Taymyr (Dolgano-Nenets) - Ust-Ordynskiy Buryat - Yamalo-Nenets - Former Kray: Far Eastern - Former Oblasti: Arzamas - Balashov - Bugulma - Chistopol - Crimea (Krym) - Grozny - Kamensk - Kazan - Nizhne Amur - Sterlitamak - Terek - Ufa - Ussuri - Vielikie Luki - Yuzhnyy-Sakhalin - Zeya - oblasti in former Kazakh A.S.S.R. - Former Cities of Republican Subordination: Chelyabinsk - Gorkiy - Krasnoyarsk - Kuybyshev - Molotov (Perm) - Novosibirsk - Omsk - Rostov-na-Donu - Saratov - Sochi - Stalingrad - Former Autonomous Oblasti: Buryat-Mongolian (of Far East) - Cherkess - Ingush - Former National Okruga: Argayashskiy - Cherkess (Circassian) - Karelian - Okhotskiy - Vitimo-Olekminskiy -

Note: Russian S.F.S.R. inherited the former administrative division in governorates (gubernii) and some oblasti, but in the period between 1922 and 1929 they were entirely reorganized into kraya and (new and initially much larger) oblasti (the difference between them was that kraya could contain autonomous oblasti and at some point even small oblasti and Autonomous Republics). Autonomous oblasti (originally known as "Labor Communes") appeared in 1918, when ethnic groups were granted their own administrative divisions equal to oblasti. Autonomous okruga (to 1978, national okruga), established from 1925 on, were merely ethnic subdivisions of kraya and oblasti along with regular okruga (almost all regular okruga were abolished in 1930). Cities of republican subordination (from 1931) were industrial centers that were economically (but not administratively) separated from respective oblasti.

Kraya and oblasti that existed after the reorganization of 1922/29 and all autonomous (national) oblasti and okruga are recorded below. By 1980 the Russian S.F.S.R. was divided into 87 entities (15 autonomous soviet socialist republics, 6 kraya, 49 oblasti, 2 cities of republican subordination, 5 autonomous oblasti, and 10 autonomous okruga). Until 1991, almost all leaders were members of the Communist Party so their party affiliation are not noted below. Non-Russian names of entities below are given in attempted transliteration of modern Cyrillic orthography of respective language. During the Soviet period these entities (apart from the autonomous republics) did not have flags. For the Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republics: see here (from 25 Dec 1991 see Russia Administrative Divisions).

Party abbreviations: KPSS = Kommunisticheskaya Partiya Sovetskogo Soyuza (Communist Party of the Soviet Union, Marxist-Leninist communist, USSR state party to 13 Mar 1990, former VKP, 13 Oct 1952 - 29 Aug 1991); KPR = Kommunisticheskaya Partiya Rossiyskoy SFSR (Communist Party of the Russian SFSR, split from KPSS, 19 Jun 1990 - 6 Nov 1991; from 14 Feb 1993 Kommunisticheskaya Partiya Rossiyskoy Federatsii)

for Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republics: see Part 1
